00020 /*
00021 *********************************************************************************************************
00022 *                                DELAY TASK 'n' TICKS   (n from 0 to 65535)
00023 *
00024 * Description: This function is called to delay execution of the currently running task until the
00025 *              specified number of system ticks expires.  This, of course, directly equates to delaying
00026 *              the current task for some time to expire.  No delay will result If the specified delay is
00027 *              0.  If the specified delay is greater than 0 then, a context switch will result.
00028 *
00029 * Arguments  : ticks     is the time delay that the task will be suspended in number of clock 'ticks'.
00030 *                        Note that by specifying 0, the task will not be delayed.
00031 *
00032 * Returns    : none
00033 *********************************************************************************************************
00034 */
00035 
00036 void  OSTimeDly (INT16U ticks)
00037 {
00038     INT8U      y;
00039 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                      /* Allocate storage for CPU status register           */
00040     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00041 #endif    
00042 
00043 
00044 
00045     if (ticks > 0) {                             /* 0 means no delay!                                  */
00046         OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00047         y            =  OSTCBCur->OSTCBY;        /* Delay current task                                 */
00048         OSRdyTbl[y] &= ~OSTCBCur->OSTCBBitX;
00049         if (OSRdyTbl[y] == 0) {  
00050             OSRdyGrp &= ~OSTCBCur->OSTCBBitY;
00051         }
00052         OSTCBCur->OSTCBDly = ticks;              /* Load ticks in TCB                                  */
00053         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00054         OS_Sched();                              /* Find next task to run!                             */
00055     }
00056 }
00057 /*$PAGE*/
00058 /*
00059 *********************************************************************************************************
00060 *                                     DELAY TASK FOR SPECIFIED TIME
00061 *
00062 * Description: This function is called to delay execution of the currently running task until some time
00063 *              expires.  This call allows you to specify the delay time in HOURS, MINUTES, SECONDS and
00064 *              MILLISECONDS instead of ticks.
00065 *
00066 * Arguments  : hours     specifies the number of hours that the task will be delayed (max. is 255)
00067 *              minutes   specifies the number of minutes (max. 59)
00068 *              seconds   specifies the number of seconds (max. 59)
00069 *              milli     specifies the number of milliseconds (max. 999)
00070 *
00071 * Returns    : OS_NO_ERR
00072 *              OS_TIME_INVALID_MINUTES
00073 *              OS_TIME_INVALID_SECONDS
00074 *              OS_TIME_INVALID_MS
00075 *              OS_TIME_ZERO_DLY
00076 *
00077 * Note(s)    : The resolution on the milliseconds depends on the tick rate.  For example, you can't do
00078 *              a 10 mS delay if the ticker interrupts every 100 mS.  In this case, the delay would be
00079 *              set to 0.  The actual delay is rounded to the nearest tick.
00080 *********************************************************************************************************
00081 */
00082 
00083 #if OS_TIME_DLY_HMSM_EN > 0
00084 INT8U  OSTimeDlyHMSM (INT8U hours, INT8U minutes, INT8U seconds, INT16U milli)
00085 {
00086     INT32U ticks;
00087     INT16U loops;
00088 
00089 
00090 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00091     if (hours == 0) {
00092         if (minutes == 0) {
00093             if (seconds == 0) {
00094                 if (milli == 0) {
00095                     return (OS_TIME_ZERO_DLY);
00096                 }
00097             }
00098         }
00099     }
00100     if (minutes > 59) {
00101         return (OS_TIME_INVALID_MINUTES);        /* Validate arguments to be within range              */
00102     }
00103     if (seconds > 59) {
00104         return (OS_TIME_INVALID_SECONDS);
00105     }
00106     if (milli > 999) {
00107         return (OS_TIME_INVALID_MILLI);
00108     }
00109 #endif
00110                                                  /* Compute the total number of clock ticks required.. */
00111                                                  /* .. (rounded to the nearest tick)                   */
00112     ticks = ((INT32U)hours * 3600L + (INT32U)minutes * 60L + (INT32U)seconds) * OS_TICKS_PER_SEC
00113           + OS_TICKS_PER_SEC * ((INT32U)milli + 500L / OS_TICKS_PER_SEC) / 1000L;
00114     loops = (INT16U)(ticks / 65536L);            /* Compute the integral number of 65536 tick delays   */
00115     ticks = ticks % 65536L;                      /* Obtain  the fractional number of ticks             */
00116     OSTimeDly((INT16U)ticks);
00117     while (loops > 0) {
00118         OSTimeDly((INT16U)32768u);
00119         OSTimeDly((INT16U)32768u);
00120         loops--;
00121     }
00122     return (OS_NO_ERR);
00123 }
00124 #endif
00125 /*$PAGE*/
00126 /*
00127 *********************************************************************************************************
00128 *                                         RESUME A DELAYED TASK
00129 *
00130 * Description: This function is used resume a task that has been delayed through a call to either
00131 *              OSTimeDly() or OSTimeDlyHMSM().  Note that you can call this function to resume a
00132 *              task that is waiting for an event with timeout.  This would make the task look
00133 *              like a timeout occurred.  
00134 *
00135 *              Also, you cannot resume a task that has called OSTimeDlyHMSM() with a combined time that 
00136 *              exceeds 65535 clock ticks.  In other words, if the clock tick runs at 100 Hz then, you will 
00137 *              not be able to resume a delayed task that called OSTimeDlyHMSM(0, 10, 55, 350) or higher:
00138 *
00139 *                  (10 Minutes * 60 + 55 Seconds + 0.35) * 100 ticks/second.
00140 *
00141 * Arguments  : prio                      specifies the priority of the task to resume
00142 *
00143 * Returns    : OS_NO_ERR                 Task has been resumed
00144 *              OS_PRIO_INVALID           if the priority you specify is higher that the maximum allowed
00145 *                                        (i.e. >= OS_LOWEST_PRIO)
00146 *              OS_TIME_NOT_DLY           Task is not waiting for time to expire
00147 *              OS_TASK_NOT_EXIST         The desired task has not been created or has been assigned to a Mutex.
00148 *********************************************************************************************************
00149 */
00150 
00151 #if OS_TIME_DLY_RESUME_EN > 0
00152 INT8U  OSTimeDlyResume (INT8U prio)
00153 {
00154     OS_TCB    *ptcb;
00155 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                                    /* Storage for CPU status register      */
00156     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00157 #endif    
00158 
00159 
00160 
00161     if (prio >= OS_LOWEST_PRIO) {
00162         return (OS_PRIO_INVALID);
00163     }
00164     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00165     ptcb = (OS_TCB *)OSTCBPrioTbl[prio];                       /* Make sure that task exist            */
00166     if (ptcb == (OS_TCB *)0) {
00167         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00168         return (OS_TASK_NOT_EXIST);                            /* The task does not exist              */
00169     }
00170     if (ptcb == (OS_TCB *)1) {
00171         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00172         return (OS_TASK_NOT_EXIST);                            /* The task does not exist              */
00173     }
00174     if (ptcb->OSTCBDly == 0) {                                 /* See if task is delayed               */
00175         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00176         return (OS_TIME_NOT_DLY);                              /* Indicate that task was not delayed   */
00177     }
00178 
00179     ptcb->OSTCBDly = 0;                                        /* Clear the time delay                 */
00180     if ((ptcb->OSTCBStat & OS_STAT_PEND_ANY) != OS_STAT_RDY) {
00181         ptcb->OSTCBStat   &= ~OS_STAT_PEND_ANY;                /* Yes, Clear status flag               */
00182         ptcb->OSTCBPendTO  = TRUE;                             /* Indicate PEND timeout                */
00183     } else {
00184         ptcb->OSTCBPendTO  = FALSE;
00185     }
00186     if ((ptcb->OSTCBStat & OS_STAT_SUSPEND) == OS_STAT_RDY) {  /* Is task suspended?                   */
00187         OSRdyGrp               |= ptcb->OSTCBBitY;             /* No,  Make ready                      */
00188         OSRdyTbl[ptcb->OSTCBY] |= ptcb->OSTCBBitX;
00189         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00190         OS_Sched();                                           /* See if this is new highest priority   */
00191     } else {
00192         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                                   /* Task may be suspended                 */
00193     }
00194     return (OS_NO_ERR);
00195 }
00196 #endif    
00197 /*$PAGE*/
00198 /*
00199 *********************************************************************************************************
00200 *                                         GET CURRENT SYSTEM TIME
00201 *
00202 * Description: This function is used by your application to obtain the current value of the 32-bit
00203 *              counter which keeps track of the number of clock ticks.
00204 *
00205 * Arguments  : none
00206 *
00207 * Returns    : The current value of OSTime
00208 *********************************************************************************************************
00209 */
00210 
00211 #if OS_TIME_GET_SET_EN > 0
00212 INT32U  OSTimeGet (void)
00213 {
00214     INT32U     ticks;
00215 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                      /* Allocate storage for CPU status register           */
00216     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00217 #endif    
00218 
00219 
00220 
00221     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00222     ticks = OSTime;
00223     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00224     return (ticks);
00225 }
00226 #endif    
00227 
00228 /*
00229 *********************************************************************************************************
00230 *                                            SET SYSTEM CLOCK
00231 *
00232 * Description: This function sets the 32-bit counter which keeps track of the number of clock ticks.
00233 *
00234 * Arguments  : ticks      specifies the new value that OSTime needs to take.
00235 *
00236 * Returns    : none
00237 *********************************************************************************************************
00238 */
00239 
00240 #if OS_TIME_GET_SET_EN > 0
00241 void  OSTimeSet (INT32U ticks)
00242 {
00243 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                      /* Allocate storage for CPU status register           */
00244     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00245 #endif    
00246 
00247 
00248 
00249     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00250     OSTime = ticks;
00251     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00252 }
00253 #endif
